solution_line_template: The discount for an iPhone 12 is ${iphone_price} x {iphone_discount_numerator}/{percentage_denominator} = $<<{iphone_price}*{iphone_discount_numerator}/{percentage_denominator}={iphone_discount_amount}>>{iphone_discount_amount}.
So, the iPhone will now cost ${iphone_price} - ${iphone_discount_amount} = $<<{iphone_price}-{iphone_discount_amount}={iphone_cost_after_discount}>>{iphone_cost_after_discount}.

The discount for an iWatch is ${iwatch_price} x {iwatch_discount_numerator}/{percentage_denominator} = $<<{iwatch_price}*{iwatch_discount_numerator}/{percentage_denominator}={iwatch_discount_amount}>>{iwatch_discount_amount}.
So, the iWatch will now cost ${iwatch_price} - ${iwatch_discount_amount} = $<<{iwatch_price}-{iwatch_discount_amount}={iwatch_cost_after_discount}>>{iwatch_cost_after_discount}.

The total cost of the iPhone and iWatch is ${iphone_cost_after_discount} + ${iwatch_cost_after_discount} = $<<{iphone_cost_after_discount}+{iwatch_cost_after_discount}={total_cost_before_cashback}>>{total_cost_before_cashback}.
